Award.AwardTitle: Optimizing the Molecular Structures, Mechanisms, and Energetics of Electron Transfer for Catalytic Production of Solar Fuels
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program and the Chemical Measurements and Imaging Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation support Professor Dennis Lichtenberger of the University of Arizona, for photoelectron spectroscopy studies of Fe-S clusters as related to solar fuels (H2) production. The goal of this work is to understand the fundamental principles of electron transfer reactions of such catalysts, synthesized in the PI's laboratory and in others. Evaluation of Marcus theory parameters for these reactions will lead to a better understanding of catalyst structure and function at the molecular level, and develop criteria for higher efficiency solar fuels generators.

Broader impacts of the research include driving innovation in solar energy applications, and contributing to scientific infrastructure by developing next-generation instrumentation and methods for photoelectron spectroscopy of large molecules. The Lichtenberger laboratory will provide access to these capabilities for other researchers, and develop curricula for undergraduate education. This laboratory has had significant success in recruiting undergraduate students, women, and underrepresented minorities into the program, including those from the Hispanic and Native American populations in the Tucson area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

One of the grand challenges facing society today is to discover the basis for an energy economy that is efficient, clean, cost-effective, and sustainable. Sunlight is our ultimate source of energy and this energy has been caught and collected over geologic time in combustible fossil fuels (i.e. oil, natural gas and coal) that currently account for the vast majority of our energy consumption, but with well-known drawbacks. In contrast, solar energy can be converted with the aid of catalysts to clean hydrogen fuel from water or to liquid fuels from carbon dioxide or other sources. Central to these processes is the movement of electrons, starting from the charge separation with absorption of light and proceeding to the catalytic reduction processes in which the electrons and the energy are stored in chemical bonds. This project seeks an understanding and approach to optimization of these electron transfer processes through unique probes of the energetics associated with the mechanisms and dynamics of electron transfer catalysis at the level of molecular geometric and electronic structure.

The initial focus of this project was on compounds containing the butterfly [2Fe-2S] cluster core as inspired by this cluster in the active sites of [FeFe]hydrogenase enzymes that produce molecular hydrogen in Nature.  We have produced synthetic catalysts containing this butterfly core structure that (1) produce hydrogen 1000 times faster than the [FeFe]hydrogenase enzymes based on the amount of iron, and one million times more efficiently based on mass, (2) use weak acids with 16 orders of magnitude less driving force than the strong acids required by most other synthetic catalysts, and (3) operate at lower voltages ("overpotential") than other catalysts, and in some cases the same voltages as the expensive platinum used in commercial electrocatalysis. Note that our synthetic catalysts are composed of inexpensive iron and sulfur. In the course of these studies we have learned the geometric and electronic factors that lead to fast electron transfer and also the factors that lead to eventual deactivation of the catalysts. With this knowledge we added to these studies investigation of dimetal complexes with strongly bound electron-rich bicyclic guanidinate ligands and discovered the most powerful electron donor complexes in non-polar liquids. This discovery has opened the door to a new realm of electron transfer reduction chemistry that was not possible previously. This research program has produced ~25 publications and 6 provisional patent applications based on these discoveries.

Broader Impacts

This program has been very successful in the professional advancement of students and postdocs, partly due to the broad experience the research associates receive from the multidisciplinary nature of this research and partly from the collaborative nature of the research and the experience of working as a team. During the period of this project seven graduate research associates (three women) completed their Ph.D. degrees and one graduate research associate completed an M.S. degree. All have gone on to attractive positions in industry, government laboratories, and academia. Sixteen undergraduate students (seven women) have also participated in the program for periods from a semester to two years.

This program also reaches out and exposes K-12 students and teachers to this science. (1) In cooperation with the ROKET program at the University of Arizona, four science teachers that are working in schools with large Native American student populations were brought into our laboratories for a period of six weeks in the summer. The purpose is to help these teachers introduce chemistry topics into their K-12 classrooms in a way that incorporates Native languages and cultures. We have learned that the sustainable conversion of solar energy into hydrogen fuel is a concept that fits naturally into the Native American Indian culture and beliefs. (2) Through the “Chemistry Discovery” program developed by Dr. Elisa Tomat with the University of Arizona Flandrau Science Center, our research students learn to develop activities that prompt middle school students to discover chemical concepts in their daily experience. They meet several times a year with middle school students for “Chemistry Discovery” workshops. (3) In conjunction with the ACS Science Coaches program, graduate students in this group work as mentors to teachers at a local Title 1 elementary school to help incorporate chemistry into underprivileged students’ science curricula through design of exciting lessons and performance of demonstrations for the students.

In terms of infrastructure for science, it is important to note that the gas-phase photoelectron spectroscopy facility maintained by this project is the only open source, multi-user facility in the United States for measuring the gas-phase valence ionization energies of large neutral molecules. Because of the importance of experimental electronic structure information and the uniqueness of our capabilities, the facility has attracted and benefited a large number of users and fostered many partnerships.
